sen.j: 天之尾羽張（あめのおはばり）は、日本神話に登場する刀であり、また神 (神道)の名前である。
sen.e: "Amenoohabari" is a sword appearing in Japanese Mythology, as well as the name of a god (Shinto).
"Amenoohabari" is a sword appearing in Japanese Mythology, as well as the name of a god (Shinto).
"Amenoohabari" is a sword appearing in Japanese Mythology, as well as the name of a god (Shinto).

sen.j: 神名としては天之尾羽張神（あめのおはばりのかみ）という。
sen.e: As shinmei (name of god), it is Amenoohabari-no-kami.
As shinmei (name of god), it is Amenoohabari-no-kami.
As a shinmei (name of god), it is called Amenoohabari-no-kami.

sen.j: 別名 伊都之尾羽張（いつのおはばり）。
sen.e: It is also referred to as Itsunoohabari.
It is also referred to as Itsunoohabari.
It is also referred to as Itsunoohabari.

sen.j: 古事記の神産みの段において、イザナギがカグツチを斬ったときに使った十束剣の名前として登場する。
sen.e: In the chapter of kamiumi (birth of the gods) in Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters), it appears as the name of Totsuka no tsurugi used by Izanagi to kill Kagutsuchi.
In the chapter of kamiumi (birth of the gods) in Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters), it appears as the name of Totsuka no tsurugi used by Izanagi to kill Kagutsuchi.
In the chapter of kamiumi (birth of the gods) in Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters), it appears as the name of Totsuka no tsurugi (long sword) used by Izanagi to kill Kagutsuchi.

sen.j: その別名が天尾羽張であると記す。
sen.e: It is written that its other name was Amenoohabari.
It is written that its other name was Amenoohabari.
It is written that its other name was Amenoohabari.

sen.j: 天尾羽張についたカグツチの血から、タケミカヅチなどの火・雷・刀に関する神が化生している。
sen.e: Gods such as Takemikazuchi related to fire, thunder, and sword were born from Kagutsuchi's blood on the Amenoohabari.
Gods such as Takemikazuchi related to fire, thunder, and sword were born from Kagutsuchi's blood on the Amenoohabari.
Gods such as Takemikazuchi related to fire, thunder, and sword were born from Kagutsuchi's blood on the Amenoohabari.

sen.j: 葦原中国平定の段では、アメノホヒ、アメノワカヒコに次ぐ三番目に葦原中国に派遣する神を選定する際、オモイカネが、伊都之尾羽張神かその神の子の建御雷之男神を推薦している。
sen.e: In the chapter on the conquest of Ashihara no nakatsukuni, upon selecting the third god to dispatch to Ashihara no nakatsukuni after Amenohohi and Amenowakahiko, Omoikane (the god of wisdom and talent) recommended Itsunoohabari-no-kami or the child of this god, Takemikazuchinoo-no-kami.

In the chapter on the conquest of Ashihara no nakatsukuni, upon selecting the third god to dispatch to Ashihara no nakatsukuni after Amenohohi and Amenowakahiko, Omoikane (the god of wisdom and talent) recommended Itsunoohabari-no-kami or the child of this god, Takemikazuchinoo-no-kami.

In the chapter on the conquest of Ashihara no nakatsukuni, upon selecting the third god to dispatch to Ashihara no nakatsukuni after Amenohohi and Amenowakahiko, Omoikane (the god of wisdom and talent) recommended Itsunoohabari-no-kami or the child of this god, Takemikazuchinoo-no-kami.

sen.j: 天尾羽張神は天安河の水を逆にせき上げて道を塞いでおり、他の神はそこへ行くことができないので、天迦久神が使者として遣わされた。
sen.e: Amenoohabari-no-kami blocked the road by pulling the water from Amenoyasukawa, and since the other gods could not go there, Amenokaku-no-kami was dispatched as an envoy.
Amenoohabari-no-kami blocked the road by pulling the water from Amenoyasukawa, and since the other gods could not go there, Amenokaku-no-kami was dispatched as an envoy.
Amenoohabari-no-kami blocked the road by pulling the water from Amenoyasukawa, and since the other gods could not go there, Amenokaku-no-kami was dispatched as an envoy.

sen.j: 伊都之尾羽張神が、建御雷之男神の方が適任であると答えたため、建御雷之男神が葦原中国に派遣されることになった。
sen.e: Itsunoohabari-no-kami responded that Takemikazuchinoo-no-kami is more qualified, so Takemikazuchinoo-no-kami was dispatched to Ashihara no nakatsukuni.
Itsunoohabari-no-kami responded that Takemikazuchinoo-no-kami is more qualified, so Takemikazuchinoo-no-kami was dispatched to Ashihara no nakatsukuni.
Itsunoohabari-no-kami responded that Takemikazuchinoo-no-kami is more qualified, so Takemikazuchinoo-no-kami was dispatched to Ashihara no nakatsukuni.

sen.j: 日本書紀の葦原中国平定の段の本文で武甕槌神が登場する際、天石窟に住む神である稜威雄走神（いつのおはしりのかみ）の四世の孫であると記されている。
sen.e: When Takemikazuchi-no-kami appears in the main body of the chapter on the conquest of Ashihara no nakatsukuni in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan), it is described that it is the grandchild of Itsunoohashiri-no-kami IV, a god living in Amenoiwaya.

When Takemikazuchi-no-kami appears in the main body of the chapter on the conquest of Ashihara no nakatsukuni in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan), it is described that it is the grandchild of Itsunoohashiri-no-kami IV, a god living in Amenoiwaya.

When Takemikazuchi-no-kami appears in the main body of the chapter on the conquest of Ashihara no nakatsukuni in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan), it is described that it is the grandchild of Itsunoohashiri-no-kami IV, a god living in Amenoiwaya.

sen.j: 稜威雄走神は天之尾羽張神の別名と見られる。
sen.e: Itsunoohashiri-no-kami is believed to be another name for Amenoohabari-no-kami.
Itsunoohashiri-no-kami is believed to be another name for Amenoohabari-no-kami.
Itsunoohashiri-no-kami is believed to be another name for Amenoohabari-no-kami.

sen.j: 「尾羽張」は「尾刃張」で、鋒の両方の刃が張り出した剣の意味である。
sen.e: Ohabari' (尾羽張) means 'ohabari' (尾刃張), which is a sword with wide blades on both sides at the tip.
Ohabari' (尾羽張) means 'ohabari' (尾刃張), which is a sword with wide blades on both sides at the tip.
Ohabari' (尾羽張) means 'ohabari' (尾刃張), which is a sword with wide blades on both sides at the tip.

sen.j: 「天」は高天原に関係のあるものであることを示す。
sen.e: Ame' indicates that it has something to do with Takamanohara (plain of high heaven).
Ame' indicates that it has something to do with Takamanohara (plain of high heaven).
Ame' indicates that it has something to do with Takamanohara (plain of high heaven).

sen.j: 「伊都」「稜威」は威力のことである。
sen.e: Itsu' (伊都, 稜威) means power.
Itsu' (伊都, 稜威) means power.
Itsu' (伊都, 稜威) means power.

sen.j: 「雄走」は「鞘走る」（さおはしる）の意で、鋭利な刃であることを示す。
sen.e: Ohashiri' means 'saohashiru' (the sword comes out of the sheath on its own) indicating that it is a sharp blade.
Ohashiri' means 'saohashiru' (the sword comes out of the sheath on its own) indicating that it is a sharp blade.
Ohashiri' means 'saohashiru' (the sword comes out of the sheath on its own) indicating that it is a sharp blade.
